Editor's choice paper Vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid and methyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone over non-noble metal-based catalysts Daolai Sun Atsutaka Ohkubo Keisuke Asami Takahiro Katori Yasuhiro Yamada Satoshi Sato ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) and methyl levulinate (ML) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) was performed over non-noble metal-based catalysts such as Cu/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and Co/SiO2. The catalytic activity and stability of the Cu-, Ni- and Co-based catalysts for the formation of GVL from ML and LA were investigated and compared at a low contact time of 0.3h. In the hydrogenation of ML to GVL, the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of ML was Cu/Al2O3 >Co/SiO2 >Ni/SiO2. Cu/Al2O3 was the most selective for the formation of GVL, whereas it was unstable in contrast to the other catalysts. In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of LA was Ni/SiO2 >Cu/Al2O3 >Co/SiO2, which is the same as the order of the catalyst stability, while Cu/Al2O3 was the most selective for the formation of GVL from LA. The reactions were also performed in N2 atmosphere in order to study the reaction pathways. Methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate was supposed to be the intermediate in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL, whereas the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL were dependent on the catalyst species. Based on the TG analysis of the used catalysts, it was found that LA led to more severe catalyst deactivation than ML did. Keywords Levulinic acid Methyl levulinate γ-valerolactone Hydrogenation Non-noble metal 1 Introduction Currently, the energy and chemical industries are highly dependent on the use of fossil resources, which have caused serious global environmental problems. Renewable biomass is attractive as an alternative resource for the production of either energy or chemicals, and many efforts in relation to the application of biomass have been made for the last decade [1–3]. Biomass-derivable levulinic acid (LA) is an attractive platform molecular for producing various useful chemicals including γ-valerolactone (GVL), which has many uses as either a solvent or an intermediate [4–7]. Liquid-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL were intensively reported over either noble metals, such as Ru [8–16], Ir [17], and Pd [18–20], or non-noble metals such as Cu [21–24] and Ni [21,25]. Higher than 97% yield of GVL was achieved over Ru [8], Pd [20], or Cu [23] catalyst, whereas Ru and Pd could work at temperatures lower than Cu. Levulinic acid ester (levulinate), which can be easily synthesized by the esterification of LA with an alcohol even at room temperature [26], is also considered as an attractive feedstock of GVL. Transition metals such as Ru [27,28], Pd [29], Cu [30] and Co [31] have been reported to be effective for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of levulinate to GVL, and ca. 90% yield of GVL are obtained. In contrast to the liquid-phase reactions, vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL was less studied. Vapor-phase continuous processes have been reported using non-noble metals such as Cu and Ni as the catalysts [32–37], and GVL yields higher than 90% could be obtained over Cu- [32] and Ni-based catalysts [35,37]. However, because the above reported vapor-phase processes were performed under low WHSV conditions with low GVL productivities, it is difficult to distinguish and compare the activity and the stability of these catalysts. In a recent report of our group, SiO2-supported Cu-Ni bimetallic catalyst showed a high and stable catalytic activity at a high WHSV of 1.65h−1, and the yield of GVL was higher than 99% at a time on stream of 50h [38]. In the case of the hydrogenation of levulinate to GVL, however, vapor-phase continuous processes have not been reported. In addition, the catalytic behavior of Co in the hydrogenation of either LA or levulinate to GVL is less reported although Co is well used as a metal catalyst. The use of base metal catalysts with low cost is the realistic way for industrial applications, therefore, we consider that it is necessary and important to compare the activity of the base metals under the same severe reaction conditions. In this study, as shown in Scheme 1 , vapor-phase hydrogenation of either LA or methyl levulinate (ML) to GVL was studied using Cu-, Ni- and Co-based catalysts at a low contact time, W/F, of 0.3h where W and F are the catalyst weight and the feed rate of reactant, respectively. The catalytic activity and stability of these catalysts in each reaction were compared. Furthermore, the reaction pathways in the formation of GVL from LA and ML over different catalysts were investigated and proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples LA and ML were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industries Co., Ltd, and they were used for the catalytic reaction without further purification. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O, which were used as the precursors of the corresponding metals, were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. SiO2 (CARiACT Q10 with mean pore diameters of 10nm, S BET =295m2 g−1) was supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd. Al2O3 (N611N, S BET =210m2 g−1) and SiO2-Al2O3 (N631L, S BET =440m2 g−1) were purchased from Nikki Chemical Co., Ltd. Active carbon (A-BAC-LP, S BET =1100–1300m2 g−1) was supplied by Kureha Corporation. Metal-loaded catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method. An aqueous solution (ca. 15cm3) of metal nitrate with a prescribed amount was firstly prepared. About 0.3cm3 of the solution was dropped onto ca. 4g of the support (pore volume, ca. 1cm3 g−1) in an operation, and then the water was evaporated at 70°C by illuminating samples using a 350-W electric light bulb at ambient pressure. Such an operation was repeated until all of the solution was dropped. After the impregnation process, the samples were dried at 110°C for 12h, and then calcined at 300°C for 3h. Hereafter, the prepared catalysts are named as x-A/B, where A indicates the species of the supported metal; B indicates the support; x means the weight percentage of the supported metal A. For example, 20-Cu/Al2O3 means a catalyst with 20wt.% Cu loaded on Al2O3 support. 2.2 Catalytic reaction Vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA and ML was conducted using a fixed-bed down-flow glass reactor with an inner diameter of 17mm at ambient H2 pressure conditions. Before starting the reaction, 0.5g catalyst was placed on the catalyst bed and preheated in H2 flow at a prescribed temperature for 1h in order to reduce the metal oxide species, and then the temperature was controlled to a determined reaction temperature. The reduction temperature for Cu-, Ni- and Co-based catalysts were 260, 380 and 380°C, respectively. The reduction temperatures of these catalysts were determined according to the H2 temperature-programmed reduction measurements [38]. After that, either pure LA or ML was fed through the top of the reactor with a liquid feed rate of 1.65g h−1 together with an H2 flow of 30cm3 min−1. The liquid effluents were collected in a dry ice-acetone trap (–78°C) every hour, and they were analyzed using a FID-GC (GC-14B, Shimadzu, Japan) with a 60-m capillary column of TC-WAX (GL-Science, Japan). The products in the effluents were identified using a GC–MS (QP5050A, Shimadzu). 1-Butanol was used as an internal standard substance. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. The thermo gravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku, Japan) for analyzing the amount of coke accumulated on the catalyst surface. The analysis conditions are as followings: sample weight, ca. 10mg; the rate of the temperature increase, 5°Cmin−1; heating range, from the room temperature to 900°C. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Hydrogenation of ML to GVL over Co-based catalysts The catalytic behavior of Co-based catalysts in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL was initially investigated. Co was loaded on various supports, such as SiO2, Al2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, and active carbon, where the loading of Co was fixed at 20wt.%. Compared to SiO2 and Al2O3, SiO2-Al2O3 has strong acidity and the large amount of acid sites, which is confirmed by NH3-TPD analysis in our previous studies [39–41]. The reactions were performed at 240°C with an H2 flow rate of 30cm3 min−1 and a W/F of 0.3h. Table 1 shows the reaction results, which are the average values between 1–5h of time on stream, and the corresponding time-on-stream profiles are shown in Fig. S1 in the supplementary file. It is obvious that the catalytic activity is dependent on the species of the support. 20-Co/Al2O3 showed poor activity, and gave a low ML conversion of 5.6%. 20-Co/SiO2-Al2O3 gave a ML conversion of 26.2%, and the selectivity to GVL was only 74.8% due to the formation of γ-butyrolactone (BL), methyl pentanoate (MP), and other unidentified products. As shown in Scheme 2 , BL was produced by the decomposition of ML via CC bond cleavage, and MP was produced by the hydrogenolysis of ML. The relatively high selectivity to BL and MP over 20-Co/SiO2-Al2O3 was considered to be attributed to the strong acidity of SiO2-Al2O3. 20-Co/C showed a conversion of 75.7%, whereas the selectivity to other products was as high as 23.2%. SiO2 support showed the best performance, and 92.7% conversion with 83.9% GVL selectivity was achieved over 20-Co/SiO2. Therefore, SiO2 was selected as the support for further studies. Fig. 1 shows the effect of Co loadings in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL at a Co loading range of 2.5–30wt.%. The conversion of ML was lower than 20% at a Co loading of 2.5wt.%, and it significantly increased with increasing the Co loading up to 20wt.%, indicating that Co was the active phase for the conversion of ML. Because large Co loading would decrease the surface area, the conversion of ML did not further increase at Co loadings higher than 20wt.%. The selectivity to GVL was high at low Co loadings, whereas it decreased with increasing the Co loading. On the other hand, the selectivity to the other products increased with increasing the Co loading. The highest GVL yield of 77.8% was obtained at a Co loading of 20wt.%, indicating that a moderate Co loading was effective for the formation of GVL from ML. Fig. 2 shows the effect of reaction temperature in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL over 20-Co/SiO2. The selectivity to GVL was higher than 95% at temperatures lower than 220°C, whereas it gradually decreased with increasing the temperature. The selectivity to other products was high at high temperatures. It is supposed that the unidentified products at high temperatures are mainly attributed to the gaseous products generated by the decomposition of ML. Angelica lactones (ALs) were detected with a sum of the selectivity to three isomers of 16.3% at 300°C, whereas they were not detected in the reactions at temperatures lower than 270°C. The conversion of ML increased with increasing the temperature up to 240°C, and it decreased to 17.2% at 300°C. It is known that ALs easily polymerized to coke especially at high temperatures [39], therefore, it is supposed that the low conversion of ML at 300°C is due to the poisoning of the active sites by the coke generated from ALs. Based on these results, it was found that 220–240°C was the preferable temperature range for the efficient conversion of ML and the selective formation of GVL over 20-Co/SiO2. Fig. 3 shows the effect of contact time, W/F, over 20-Co/SiO2 at 240°C. The conversion of ML and the selectivity to other products increased with increasing W/F, while the selectivity to GVL decreased. It is supposed that high W/F conditions promote the decomposition of ML. A high GVL selectivity of 96.9% with a conversion of 84.4% was achieved at a W/F of 0.18h, indicating that 20-Co/SiO2 was an effective catalyst for the vapor-phase hydrogenation of ML to GVL at low W/F conditions. 3.2 Comparison of Cu-, Ni- and Co-supported catalysts in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL Although Cu and Ni are effective for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [32–37], their catalytic activities in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL have not been reported. In this section, Cu and Ni were supported on either SiO2 or Al2O3 with a fixed loading of 20wt.%, and the activity of these catalysts was compared with 20-Co/SiO2 under the same reaction conditions: temperature, 240°C;W/F, 0.3h. 20wt.% was the suitable loading for Cu and Ni on either SiO2 or Al2O3, which was confirmed by the individual tests. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic activity of the supported Cu and Ni together with 20-Co/SiO2. The catalytic activity is affected by support materials. In contrast to the poor activity of 20-Cu/SiO2, 20-Cu/Al2O3 gave a high ML conversion of 93.7% with a high GVL selectivity of 91.5%. 20-Cu/Al2O3 was further investigated under different W/F conditions (Fig. 4 ). The conversion of ML increased with increasing W/F, whereas the selectivity to GVL decreased, which is similar to the results of 20-Co/SiO2. However, the decrease of GVL selectivity under high W/F conditions was mainly attributed to the increased formation of MP. This indicates that high W/F conditions prefer the formation of MP, and that low W/F conditions are effective for the selective formation of GVL from ML over 20-Cu/Al2O3. In the case of Ni, 20-Ni/SiO2 gave a GVL selectivity of 88.4%, which is higher than that of 81.7% over 20-Ni/Al2O3. The decomposition products of ML, such as BL, methyl propionate (MPr), 2-butanone and 2-butanol, were detected in the reactions over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Ni/Al2O3, indicating that Ni readily promoted the decomposition of ML. Since 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2, and 20-Co/SiO2 showed the best performance in the Cu-, Ni-, and Co-supported catalysts, respectively, they were selected for further investigation and comparison. Under the reaction conditions shown in Table 2, the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of ML was 20-Cu/Al2O3 >20-Co/SiO2 >20-Ni/SiO2. 20-Cu/Al2O3 was also the most selective catalyst for the formation of GVL from ML among the supported catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the diffraction patterns of 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2, and 20-Co/SiO2 after reduction at 260, 380 and 380°C, respectively. Diffraction peaks of Cu at 2θ=43.4 and 50.5° (JCPDS file 4-836), Ni at 2θ=44.5 and 51.9° (JCPDS file 4-850), and Co at 2θ=44.4° (JCPDS file 15-806) were observed, indicating that the catalysts were reduced to metal state before the reaction and worked as the metal state during the reaction. Fig. 6 shows the catalyst stability of 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2, and 20-Co/SiO2 at 240°C with a W/F of 0.3h. Some reaction parameters such as the reaction temperature and the amount of the collected products are usually unstable in 0–1h of the reaction, which decreases the reliability of the data achieved in the initial 1h. Therefore, the data of 1–5h was used for evaluating the catalytic stability. The conversion of ML over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 were stable at a time on stream between 1 and 5h, whereas that over 20-Cu/Al2O3 gradually decreased with time on stream. In order to evaluate the amount of coke accumulated on the catalyst surface during the reaction, TG analyses of 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2, and 20-Co/SiO2 catalysts used after the reaction were performed (Fig. 7 ). The weight loss at 100–600°C, which is considered to be attributed the decomposition of coke [40], was observed in all the samples, indicating that coke was formed on the surface of these catalysts. Since TG analysis was performed in air atmosphere, the oxidation of the loaded metals occurred during the analysis accompanied with the decomposition of the coke. Therefore, slight weight increment was observed at 300–400°C in some of the TG profiles. The weight loss in the used 20-Cu/Al2O3 was larger than those in the used 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2, indicating that more coke was accumulated on the surface of 20-Cu/Al2O3. This result is consistent with the unstable catalytic activity of 20-Cu/Al2O3, and indicates that the catalyst deactivation is mainly caused by the formation of coke. 3.3 Hydrogenation of LA to GVL over Cu-, Ni-, and Co-based catalysts Vapor-phase hydrogenation of LA to GVL over Cu- and Ni-based catalysts has been previous reported by some groups [32–37]. In the report of Uprare et al., quantitative yield was achieved over Cu/SiO2 at a time on stream of 100h at 265°C, when the reaction was performed at a high H2 pressure of 10MPa with a low weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.5h−1 [32]. In the report of Mohan et al., who performed the reaction over Ni/ZSM-5 at an ambient H2 pressure with a relatively high WHSV of 1.0h−1, the yield of GVL was 92.2% in the initial 1h, whereas it gradually decreased to ca. 60% at a time on stream of 5h, indicating the serious catalyst deactivation. The reports suggest that H2 pressure and WHSV are important factors for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, and we consider that the real ability of catalysts should be evaluated at severe reaction conditions. Therefore, in the present study, the hydrogenation of LA to GVL was performed under an ambient H2 pressure with a high WHSV of 3.3h-1, i.e. W/F of 0.3h. Table 3 shows the reaction results in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over Cu-, Ni-, and Co-based catalysts. The Cu- and Ni-based catalysts with different supports as well as 20-Co/SiO2 were tested at a temperature of 250°C. 20-Cu/Al2O3 showed a better performance than 20-Cu/SiO2, and gave a high GVL selectivity of 97.1% with a LA conversion of 97.9%. The formation of ALs was not observed in the reaction over 20-Cu/Al2O3, whereas three isomers of ALs were produced with a sum of the selectivity of 9.9% in the reaction over 20-Cu/SiO2. The complete conversion of LA was obtained over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. 20-Ni/SiO2 showed a GVL selectivity of 89.1%, which is higher than 83.8% over 20-Ni/Al2O3. The higher performance of Al2O3 support for Cu and the higher performance of SiO2 support for Ni are consistent with those in the case of the hydrogenation of ML to GVL. Compared to Cu- and Co-based catalysts, Ni-based catalysts showed relatively high selectivities to C3 and C4 products, which were produced by the decomposition of LA (Scheme 3 ). On the other hand, in contrast to Cu- and Ni-based catalysts, 20-Co/SiO2 showed a low activity for the formation of GVL from LA. The conversion and the selectivity to GVL were 69.4 and 58.8% over 20-Co/SiO2, respectively, while the selectivity to ALs was as high as 11.2%. In order to study the effect of the reaction temperature, reactions were performed over 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2, and 20-Co/SiO2 at a high temperature of 300°C (Table 3). Over 20-Cu/Al2O3, no significant change was observed between at 250 and 300°C. In the case of 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2, however, high temperatures decreased both the conversion and the selectivity to GVL, but increased the selectivity to ALs. In our previous study, SiO2 was found to be effective for the cyclodehydration of LA to ALs at high temperatures such as 300°C [39]. Therefore, it is reasonable that SiO2 support in 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 is the active phase for the formation of ALs from LA. Generally, high reaction temperature is not preferable for a hydrogenation process. Thus, the formed ALs cannot be efficiently converted to GVL, resulting in the high selectivities to ALs and the low selectivities to GVL. The decrease in the conversion of LA over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 at 300°C was attributed to the catalyst deactivation, which could be caused by the by-production of ALs with large amounts because ALs easily polymerize to coke and poison the catalysts [39]. Fig. 8 shows the effect of W/F in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 at 250°C. The conversion of LA increased with increasing W/F in all the cases (Fig. 8a). Judging from the LA conversions at 250°C under low W/F conditions, it can be concluded that the order of the catalytic activity for the LA hydrogenation is 20-Ni/SiO2>20-Cu/Al2O3 >20-Co/SiO2. On the other hand, the behaviors of the catalysts in the dependence of GVL selectivity on W/F were much different. Over 20-Ni/SiO2, high W/F conditions promoted the decomposition of LA and decreased the selectivity to GVL. However, 20-Co/SiO2 showed a converse behavior that the selectivity to GVL increased with increasing W/F, and the selectivity to GVL reached to 95.0% at a high W/F of 1.3h. On the other hand, the selectivity to ALs over 20-Co/SiO2 was 16.6% at a W/F of 0.2h, and it gradually decreased to 0% at a high W/F of 1.3h. In contrast, the selectivity to GVL was not significantly affected by W/F over 20-Cu/Al2O3, indicating that the reaction pathways over 20-Co/SiO2 and 20-Cu/Al2O3 could be different, which will be discussed in the Section 3.4. Fig. 9 shows the changes in conversion with time on stream in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 at 250°C with a W/F of 0.3h 20-Ni/SiO2 showed stable conversions at 100%, whereas the decrease in conversion was observed over 20-Cu/Al2O3 and 20-Co/SiO2. The conversion of LA decreased from 100 to 97% over 20-Cu/Al2O3 within the initial 5h, while it significantly decreased from 96 to 61% over 20-Co/SiO2. The results indicate that the order of the catalyst stability in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL is 20-Ni/SiO2 >20-Cu/Al2O3 >20-Co/SiO2. Fig. S2 shows the XRD profiles of 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 catalysts before and after the reaction. The peak intensity of either Cu in 20-Cu/Al2O3 or Co in 20-Co/SiO2 significantly decreased after the reaction, indicating the leaching of the supported metal in LA atmosphere during the reaction. In contrast, the peak intensity of Ni in 20-Ni/SiO2 was maintained after the reaction, indicating that Ni was less leached during the reaction, which would contribute to the stable catalytic activity of 20-Ni/SiO2. In addition, ammonia water was added to the collected products in order to check the leaching of Cu. The color of the liquid products in the reaction over 20-Cu/Al2O3 was changed to light blue after the addition of ammonia water, demonstrating the leaching of Cu during the reaction. Fig. 10 shows TG analysis of the used catalysts. Because the weight loss is mainly attributed to coke deposited on the catalyst, the order of the coke amount in used catalysts is 20-Co/SiO2 >20-Cu/Al2O3 >20-Ni/SiO2, which is the converse order compared to that of the catalyst stability. Therefore, the order is consistent with the order of dehydrogenation activity because the coke formation is initiated by the dehydrogenation. Besides the leaching of the metal, the catalyst deactivation would be also due to the formation of coke. Because 20-Ni/SiO2 is relatively active for the decomposition of LA (Table 3), it would be also active for the decomposition of the coke on the catalyst surface. This could be a reason for the stable catalytic activity of 20-Ni/SiO2. On the other hand, in contrast to the hydrogenation of ML to GVL over 20-Co/SiO2, the decrease in conversion is significant and more coke was formed in the used 20-Co/SiO2 in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, indicating that LA leads to more severe catalyst deactivation than ML. 3.4 Investigation of the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of either LA or ML to GVL There is an argument about the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of either LA or ML to GVL. As shown in Schemes 4 and 5 , there are two possible routes for the formation of GVL from LA or ML. A route is that ALs are generated as the intermediates, which are further hydrogenated to form GVL. Another route is that 4-hydroxypentanoic acid and methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate are generated as the intermediate, and GVL is produced through the dehydration and demethanol process, respectively. In order to confirm the reaction pathways, the reactions over 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 catalysts were performed in N2 atmosphere instead of H2. In the reaction of ML, in contrast to the high conversions of ML over 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 in H2 atmosphere (Table 2), the conversions of ML were lower than 10% in N2 atmosphere (Table 4 ). In addition, the formation of ALs was not observed in N2 atmosphere in the reactions. These results indicate that the poor activity of these catalysts for the lactonization of ML to ALs through demethanol process. Therefore, it is probable that GVL is produced form ML via methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate as the intermediate (Scheme 4). Although methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate was not detected in the reactions, it is readily converted to GVL through lactonization because of its high reactivity. Methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate can be also converted to MP, while the formation of GVL is preferable. In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, some propositions in relation to the reaction pathways have been reported. Based on the studies over Ni/TiO2, Kumar et al. have proposed that ALs are the intermediates [37]. On the other hand, it is reported by Mohan et al. that the reaction pathways are dependent on the catalysts: ALs are the intermediate over Ni/HZSM-5, while 4-hydroxypentanoic acid is the intermediate over Ni/SiO2 [35,36]. In the present study, as shown in Table 4, the conversion of LA over 20-Cu/Al2O3 in N2 was only 2.0% with a GVL selectivity 78.1%, suggesting that GVL is mainly produced via 4-hydroxypentanoic acid as an intermediate over 20-Cu/Al2O3. In the case of 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2, the conversions of LA were 21.8 and 23.8% in N2 atmosphere with GVL selectivities of 26.5 and 71.5%, respectively. The low GVL selectivity of 26.5% over 20-Co/SiO2 is considered to be attributed to the further conversion of ALs to unidentified polymeric products. The conversions of LA over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 in N2 flow were much lower than those in H2 flow (Table 3), indicating that GVL was possibly produced from LA through both the pathways. It has to be mentioned that the lactonization of LA to ALs is an equilibrium reaction [39], and the conversion of LA to ALs would be promoted in H2 atmosphere because ALs are immediately converted to GVL in H2 atmosphere that would decrease the partial pressure of ALs and shift the equilibrium from LA to ALs. Therefore, the low conversions over 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 in N2 flow do not mean that the formation of GVL via 4-hydroxypentanoic acid is the major route. In the case of 20-Ni/SiO2, however, there is no strong evidence to prove which the major route is. Over 20-Co/SiO2, low W/F conditions prefer the formation of ALs and high W/F conditions prefer the formation of GVL (Table 4), which indicates that high W/F conditions promote the hydrogenation of ALs to form GVL and strongly suggests that the formation of GVL via ALs is the major route. Based on the above results, the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL over the 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 are proposed as shown in Scheme 5. 4 Conclusions Vapor-phase hydrogenation of ML and LA to GVL was performed over various non-noble metal catalysts including Cu, Ni and Co. The catalytic activity of Co metal was firstly investigated in the vapor-phase reactions, and it was found that 20-Co/SiO2 was an effective catalyst for the hydrogenation of ML and LA to GVL. In contrast to the previous reports, the reactions in this study were performed under severe reaction conditions such as the low contact time of 0.3h. The real activity and stability of the non-noble metals were investigated and compared under the conditions. The support materials affected the catalytic activity of the non-noble metals: Al2O3 support showed a better performance than SiO2 in the case of Cu, whereas SiO2 showed a better performance than Al2O3 in the case of Ni and Co. The catalytic activity and stability of 20-Cu/Al2O3, 20-Ni/SiO2 and 20-Co/SiO2 catalysts at a metal loading of 20wt.% was investigated and compared. 20-Ni/SiO2 showed relatively high activity for the decomposition of either ML or LA, which decreased the selectivity to GVL, compared with 20-Cu/Al2O3 and 20-Co/SiO2. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of 20-Ni/SiO2 was the most stable and the amount of coke in the used 20-Ni/SiO2 was the smallest. At a low contact time, W/F, of 0.3h, 20-Cu/Al2O3 showed the most selective performance for the formation of GVL from ML, whereas it gradually deactivated with time on stream. Over 20-Co/SiO2, a high GVL selectivity of 95% was achieved from ML over 20-Co/SiO2 at a low W/F of 0.18h, whereas it decreased at high W/F. In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, the order of the catalytic activity for LA conversion is 20-Ni/SiO2 >20-Cu/Al2O3 >20-Co/SiO2, which is also the same as the order of the catalyst stability. 20-Cu/Al2O3 was the most selective catalyst for the formation of GVL from LA. The reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of ML and LA were found to be different. Methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate was the intermediate in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL, while the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL were dependent on the species of the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) and methyl levulinate (ML) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) was performed over non-noble metal-based catalysts such as Cu/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and Co/SiO2. The catalytic activity and stability of the Cu-, Ni- and Co-based catalysts for the formation of GVL from ML and LA were investigated and compared at a low contact time of 0.3h. In the hydrogenation of ML to GVL, the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of ML was Cu/Al2O3 >Co/SiO2 >Ni/SiO2. Cu/Al2O3 was the most selective for the formation of GVL, whereas it was unstable in contrast to the other catalysts. In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, the order of the catalytic activity for the conversion of LA was Ni/SiO2 >Cu/Al2O3 >Co/SiO2, which is the same as the order of the catalyst stability, while Cu/Al2O3 was the most selective for the formation of GVL from LA. The reactions were also performed in N2 atmosphere in order to study the reaction pathways. Methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate was supposed to be the intermediate in the hydrogenation of ML to GVL, whereas the reaction pathways in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL were dependent on the catalyst species. Based on the TG analysis of the used catalysts, it was found that LA led to more severe catalyst deactivation than ML did.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor-phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid and methyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone over non-noble metal-based catalysts
